epigraph.p: Pollyanna The glad play , by Catherine Chisholm Cushing , after the novel by Eleanor H. Porter . 5 males , 6 females . 2 interiors . Costumes , modern . Plays 2-1 / 4 hours . An orphan girl is thrust into the home of a maiden aunt . In spite of the trials that beset her , she manages to find something to be glad about , and brings light into sunless lives . Finally Pollyanna straightens out the love affairs of her elders , and finds happiness for herself in Jimmy . “ Pollyanna ” gives a better appreciation of people and the world . It reflects the humor and humanity that gave the story such wonderful popularity among young and old .

epigraph.p: Martha By-the-Day An optimistic comedy in 3 acts , by Julie M. Lippmann , author of the “ Martha ” stories . 5 males . 5 females . 3 interiors . Costumes , modern . Plays 2-1 / 2 hours . Full of quaint humor , old-fashioned , homely sentiment , the kind that people who see the play will recall and chuckle over tomorrow and the next day . Miss Lippmann has herself adapted her successful book for the stage and has selected from her novel the most telling incidents , infectious comedy and homely sentiment for the play , and the result is thoroughly delightful . Royalty , $ 25 . Price , 60 cents . Seventeen A comedy of youth , in 4 acts , by Booth Tarkington . 8 males , 6 females . 1 exterior . 2 interiors . Costumes , modern . Plays 2-1 / 2 hours . It is the tragedy of William Sylvanus Baxter that he has ceased to be sixteen and is not yet eighteen . Seventeen is not an age , it is a disease . In his heart William knows all the tortures and delights of love . But he is still sent by his mother on errands of the most humiliating sort and depends on his father for every nickel , the use of which he must justify before he gets it . “ Silly ” Bill fell in love with Lola , the “ Baby-Talk Lady , ” a vapid little flirt . To woo her in a manner worthy of himself ( and of her ) he steals his father 's evening clothes . When his wooings become a nuisance to the neighborhood , his mother steals them back , and has them let out to fit the middle-aged form of her husband , thereby keeping William at home . But when it comes to the “ Baby-Talk Lady 's ” good-bye dance , not to be present was unendurable . Now William again gets the dress suit , and how he wears it at the party , and Genesis discloses the fact that the proud garment is in reality his father 's makes up the story of the play . “ Seventeen ” is a work of exquisite human sympathy and delicious humor . div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: SCENE : Room 1121 , Manhattan Hotel , New York City .

At rise stage dark . Moonlight streams through the window . Small clock strikes five . Pause . Tower clock strikes . Two gun-shots heard off stage right . Door slams off stage . Footsteps heard coming along corridor , growing hubbub and commotion . PRINCESS pokes head through curtains . R. door bursts open and WARREN JARVIS enters hurriedly , in long coat over evening dress , closing and bolting the door behind him .

div.stage: Princess . Madre de Dios ! ( Showing only her head . ) ( JARVIS kicks in door , shuts it , and throws his shoulder against it . ) Who 's there ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Sh ! Do n't make any noise .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Winding her dressing gown closely about her and coming a little way into the roomWhat do you want ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Silence !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Switches on lamp on right tableHow dare you enter !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Sh ! Not a sound — do you understand ?

sp.speaker: VOICE OFF
sp.p: R .What 's the row ?

sp.speaker: SECOND VOICE
sp.p: R .Somebody fired a pistol .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What right —?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Quiet !

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: Where 'd he go ? Look on the fire-escape .

sp.speaker: SECOND VOICE
sp.p: No , he 's on this floor .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What is it ? What do you want here ? What have you done ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Turning to herNow , it 's all right . I 'm not going to harm you . If you will just keep quiet . Is that clear to you ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Is it money you want ? All the money I have is on that dressing table .Pointing .Take it and go .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I 'm not a burglar . I do n't want your money .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , then , what do you want ?Sound of running in corridor coming toward door R .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Listen ——Turns back to door .They 're coming here .To PRINCESSThey must n't search this room , do you understand — you must put them off — I 'm not what you think I am .Running dies away . JARVIS turns to PRINCESS .Is there no way out through that door ?Indicates door 5R .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: That is my maid 's room .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The fire-escape — where is it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: In the hall opposite .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I thought that red light meant in here . Hell ! I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , why do n't you go ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I can n't go that way .Indicating door 6L .They 'll be waiting for me in the hall .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , what do you expect me to do ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The light fooled me . I thought that door led to the fire-escape .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You said that before .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Is the situation so amusing ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I 'm not laughing at you . I blundered in here by mistake . I 'm in a tight fix . I can n't leave by that door . I must find some other .Sees door 8 , across to door 8 , and , disgusted , exclaims when he sees there is no way out there . Notices blood on hand and starts to put handkerchief around it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Going down stage C .What 's happened ? You 're wounded ! Those shots I heard ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I almost stopped one of the bullets .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Your hand is bleeding .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Please — I do n't see how the devil ——Runs up and puts up shade at window 3 , sees there is no way out .Damn !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You have evidently shot someone and are making me shield you from justice .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Coming downNo , not from justice — but from the law .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I thought they were the same .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: No , not always — there would be no justice for me at the hands of the law .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , that is not for me to decide .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: But you shall decide — at least you shall listen and if you find me guilty — I 'll — well , I 'll take that door or , or anything you say .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Your presumption is indeed ridiculous .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Hardly ridiculous — I am arguing for my life .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Can any decision be more unjust than mine must be at the point of a pistol ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Lays pistol on dressing table L. and crosses to R. of PRINCESS .There is nothing to prevent your calling for help now — after all , it does n't matter much whether the end comes today or the day after .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: The end ? Then why do n't you give yourself up ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That would not have been the end . You do n't understand , I know , but I 'm not flying from Justice . There was in this a case of shoot or be shot .Sound of running toward door 6 .Listen — they 're here now .JARVIS crosses door 8 .

sp.speaker: HOUSE DETECTIVE
sp.p: Knock outside doorAnybody in here ?Knock .Open the door .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: It 's up to you to do with me as you like .Princess points to door L. JARVIS exits .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Off stage door 5Madame — Madame —Enters .What is it ?Running to mistress for protection .Something dreadful must have happened .Knock on door repeated .What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Open it , Nita .NITA opens door reluctantly .

sp.speaker: HOUSE DETECTIVE
sp.p: In doorwayAre you all right in here ?

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Holding door openSi — Señor .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What is it , Nita ?

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Indicating PRINCESSMy mistress , Señor .

sp.speaker: HOUSE DETECTIVE
sp.p: Inside of door — removing hatExcuse me , madame , I 'm the house detective . Are you all right in here ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HOUSE DETECTIVE
sp.p: We 're sorry to bother you , but we 're looking for someone and we thought he might have come in here . If you want anything we 'll be out here in the hall . Good night !

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Shuts door and runs to PRINCESS C .Forgive me , Madame , but I am so frightened . What is it ? What is it ?

lg.l: Control yourself , Nita . Go to bed , child .
I wo n't need you till six o'clock .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Entering L. C .Thank you . Would you mind bolting that door again ? He might return .PRINCESS crosses to door and bolts it .Do you know what a feud is ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Feud ? Spain is the home of feuds .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: So is Kentucky . That 's where I came from . You 're Spanish ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Then you 'll understand — those shots you heard , that was the end of a feud . I was called home suddenly by the death of my father — shot in the back — feud — man after man — two families — the Marcums and my own had shot each other down . Then my Dad fell and I was left to fight it out alone .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Could n't you ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Could n't I ? God only knows what I 've been through since . Those two shots you heard — that was the finish . This morning when I got back to my hotel , there was a message waiting for me . It was signed Jim Marcum , head of the family , and proposed that , as we were out of Kentucky , we meet and end the feud amicably . He asked me to meet him at this hotel in his room — no matter what hour — he would be waiting . He was leaving at six in the morning and wanted it settled . It was a pretty scheme . I knew the man and I saw the trap . I came over here prepared and went directly to his room . It was on this floor . I flung open the door and met Jim Marcum face to face . He was waiting . Without a word he fired . I fired , and he dropped . Now do you understand why the law would not give me justice ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Did you kill him ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I do n't know — I did n't wait .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I do n't know . Do you know what it means to fight single-handed against fearful odds — to fight an endless fight alone ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes — yes — I know .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Endless fight — without even a single word of encouragement ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , I know what it means .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You know ? How could you know ? How could any woman know ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , I do know , because I too am fighting against fearful odds .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: There is no man to fight for you ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: No man left who dares .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: God , if there had only been some woman to fight for in my fight !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Your mother ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: She 's gone , too .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Are you alone ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Alone .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: If you 're caught it means your life .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Suppose I decide to help you ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You have no fear of death ? You are not afraid of ghosts ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: No , I 'm not afraid of ghosts .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: If you escape from here it will be because I helped you — we might say I saved your life , if what you tell me is true — and if I do it , it will be from a selfish motive entirely — it will be because I have work for you . Do you understand ? Work — hard work — dangerous work . It may mean your life in the end .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You are frank , anyway .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: It 's a chance — and you have nothing to lose .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: And if I agree ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You will begin by taking the ancient feudal oath of my country .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oath ? Is n't my word good enough ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You will pardon me if I insist .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Very well — I 'll swear the blackest oath you can utter . Let 's hear it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What 's your name ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Jarvis .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Your full name ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Warren Jarvis .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Kneel , then , Warren of Jarvis .JARVIS kneels on both knees .No , not that way — on one knee .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I beg your pardon ——

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Now repeat this oath : “ I , Warren of Jarvis —— ”

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: “ I , Warren of Jarvis —— ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: “ Señor of all the domains , fiefs , keeps and marshes of Warren of Kentucky —— ”

lg.l: Whew —— “ Señor of all the domains , fiefs , keeps and marshes of
Warren of Kentucky — ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: “ Do convey to Maria Theresa , of Aragon , all my worldly titles and possessions —— ” Now take my left hand in both of yours and repeat , “ — and receive them back as vassal and retainer . ”

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: “ And receive them back as vassal and retainer . ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: “ And do faithfully fight in my lady 's cause according to the feudal laws of Castile and Aragon . ”

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: “ And do faithfully fight in my lady 's cause according to the feudal laws of Castile and Aragon . ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Arise , vassal .JARVIS arises and kisses her hand .That is part of the ceremony , but I meant to omit it .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I thought that the only sensible part . I beg your pardon — but who on earth is this Maria Theresa that I am hired man to ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I — am Her Highness — Maria Theresa — Princess of Aragon .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Good night ! You a Princess ! And I have been ordering you around with a gun .Sound of running for a moment .Sh !Crosses to door R ., listens .It 's all right , but how am I going to get out ? They 've got me in a trap here .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: The trunk ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The trunk ? What about it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I am sending it on board the Aquitania at six o'clock .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Dragging trunk down stageYou mean to get in it ? Good Lord , is it big enough ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I think so — and no one could possibly suspect ——JARVIS takes out trays — locket drops out — back to audience .Oh ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: It 's nothing — I mean it 's all right — it 's just a locket .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Did I break it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: No ——JARVIS takes contents out of trunk .I broke it myself on purpose — yesterday . It means a great deal to me and perhaps to you . Some day you may know the reason why .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Gets in trunkWould you mind putting this lid down ?PRINCESS puts down lid of trunk on JARVIS . Grunts .O-oo-ou-ugh !Raises lid and stands up in trunk . PRINCESS raises lid all the way back as soon as JARVIS shouts .I 'll die in there .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But it 's a chance .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You 're right ! I 'll take it .Gets out of trunk and goes to trays .What are we going to do with these ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: We had better send those by messenger .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: TurningHold on — I 've got it . No , you had better ‘ phone .PRINCESS crosses to ‘ phone R .Ask the operator to give you the Hotel Belmont , across the street . My room is 417 . Rusty , my servant , is there now , waiting for word from me .He crosses to PRINCESS .He can be trusted . Tell him to come here at once — and say “ Warren . ” That will fetch him .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: 417 ? Hello —— Connect me with the Hotel Belmont , please .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Remember , ask for room 417 .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , I know . Hello , hello ! Is this the Belmont ?— Give me room 417 .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Ask if it 's Rusty and be sure and say “ Warren . ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Hello — is this Mr. Rusty ? Well , listen carefully . You are to come right over to the Manhattan Hotel , across the street from where you are . A bellboy will be waiting for you at the desk , and he is to bring you right up to room 1121 .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: And tell him to keep his mouth shut ——

lg.l: And — and — do n't talk to anyone .... What 's that ? “ Warren . ”
He 'll be coming right over .
Now get the clerk downstairs , and tell them to look out for
Rusty and send him up here .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Hello , hello ! I 'm expecting a man —

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: A colored man .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: A colored man . To get some things . He will come right to the desk . Please send him up at once . It is very important .JARVIS takes out knife and begins boring hole in trunk from inside out . This hole should be already cut and covered with a label .What are you doing that for ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Got to breathe . I think I can ——Apparently the knife breaks .Confound it !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What did you do ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Snapped the blade . Now how am I going to cut a hole in that trunk ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Crossing to dresserWill my shears do ?

lg.l: If they are not too large . Where are they ?
Thank you . What time does the boat sail ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Nine o'clock .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Good — that will give Rusty time to get aboard with these trays and my baggage .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: We 've ten minutes before they call for the trunk .Knock at door 6 . PRINCESS looks at JARVIS , who makes gesture cautioning silence and exits door L. PRINCESS crosses and opens door .Come in , please .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Enter across centerWhere 's Marse Warren ——?Enter JARVIS across to RUSTY .Lord bless you , Marse Warren — I certainly thought he got you !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Patting RUSTY on the backNever mind what you thought . Help me with these — it 's ten minutes to six — we sail for Europe in three hours .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Three hours ! Good Lord ! You mean we ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , you and I . What are we going to wrap these in ?Picking up trays .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Here , this will do .Handing steamer rug from chair .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Fine !Spreading steamer rug on trunk and putting tray on it , wraps up tray during speech .Take these , with our baggage , to the steamship Aquitania — Cunard Line . Buy accommodations . Mind , you wo n't see me till after we get out at sea . Keep in your stateroom and sit tight till you hear from me . You understand ? Cunard Line — and the clerk at our hotel will attend to everything and get the tickets . Then you pay the bill . Now get hold of this money .JARVIS gives RUSTY money .I beg your pardon ! This is Rusty . Rusty , this is the Princess of Aragon .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: How do you do , Mrs. Princess ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: There — that will do . Now do you understand ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yes , sir . I take everything to the steamboat — get accom — ac-commoda — accommoda ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Accommodations .

lg.l: Accomo — accommoda —— I know what you mean .
For us and Mrs. Princess ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: No , no — not for the Princess — just for we two .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Oh , yas , sir , I understand perfectly , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Gives parcel to RUSTYNow , then , what 's the name of the boat ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: The Aqui-tania .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What 's the name of the line ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: The Cunard .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Now be off , and do n't miss that boat .PRINCESS opens door .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: ExitingNo , sir , I wo n't miss it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: As RUSTY reaches doorGood-bye , Rusty .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: TurningGood-bye , Miss — er — Princess .

div.stage: JARVIS resumes work on trunk . PRINCESS crosses to JARVIS .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Can you do it ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I think so — yes , it 's going — there it goes — through !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Make another .She crosses to the dresser .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Have n't time . I 'll widen this one a little . Remember this trunk must not go in the hold of the ship . Have it marked “ Wanted ” and “ This end up . ” I will lie with my head this way . I 'll put the shears in here , and I can cut another hole from the inside if it gets too stuffy .

lg.stage: Takes revolver from dressing table and gives it to JARVIS
lg.l: And you better take this , too .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: How do you know you can trust me ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I do n't — I have to take that chance .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You must have a pretty good reason .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Now , before I get in this , there 's just one or two things I would like to know . What about the ghost ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Are you afraid ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Lord , no , I just wanted to know — that 's all .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You 'll know in time , Mr. Jarvis .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Are you really — a sure thing — Princess ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why did you say that ?

lg.l: Oh , I do n't know . Somehow you 're not quite like what I thought a
Princess would be .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oh , I did n't mean it that way . I mean that you 're different from the popular idea of a Princess . You have more understanding — more sympathy — more heart .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: IcilyIn that respect , sir , you will find me quite like your popular idea .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: SquelchedI wonder if that hole will let in enough air ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I hope so .PORTER knocks .It must be the men for the trunk . Who is it , please ?

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Trunks .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Getting into trunkRemember ? This trunk must not go into the hold of the ship . You must have it marked “ Wanted ” and “ This side up . ” You might add , “ With Care , ” if you 've a mind to .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Are you all right ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: No .

div.stage: Illustration : “ THE GHOST BREAKER ” See Page 17

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Shuts trunk , crosses and opens doorThe trunk is ready .

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Enter and cross with truck L. of trunkVery good , ma'am .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Have the other trunks gone ?

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Yes 'm , last night .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: This goes on the special wagon , Porter .

div.stage: Enter HOUSE DETECTIVE and sees broken door .

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Setting trunk on endYes , mum . I 'll see that a special sticker is put on it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Crosses left of trunkHave it marked “ Wanted ” and “ This end up . ”

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Putting trunk on truckYou 'll find it in your room when you get down to the steamer .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: And , Porter , handle it gently .

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.p: Shore , I never smashed one in my life .Starts off R .I 'll handle it like it had glass on the inside , so do n't worry one little bit .

lg.l: Just a minute ,
Porter . How did that lock get broken ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Frightened , but trying not to show itIt was broken when I came .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: How long have you been here ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: We came yesterday .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: How long are you going to stay ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: We sail this morning for Europe .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Huh ! Excuse me , Madame , but the police are making an investigation and they would like to take in this room . Do you mind ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: What time does your boat sail ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: We are sailing at nine o'clock .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Does this trunk go on board ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: RelievedYes , I want it to go on a special wagon .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: All right , Porter . Go ahead .Exit PORTER with trunk . To the Police who are supposed to be off R .Come in . CURTAIN ACT II

div.stage: SCENE : An elegantly furnished stateroom on the S. S. Aquitania . AT RISE is empty , shuffling and murmuring of crowd on deck . “ All visitors ashore ! ” heard in distance .

Door L ., leading to promenade deck outside ; door R. leading to another room ; windows or portholes in rear looking out ; closet down R. Lights full up , amber and white . Trunk that was carried off stage in first act discovered stage C ., wrong side up . Markings that were put on it first act are now upside down . Trunk on end . When curtain rises up trunk begins to rock back and forth as though something inside was trying to turn it over . When probable laugh has died away , door L. opens . Stateroom STEWARD is showing PRINCESS and NITA in .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Opening door L. and standing aside to allow PRINCESS and NITA to enter . PRINCESS enters first and trunk upside down immediately catches her eye . When PRINCESS well in room , enter NITA , who stumbles over raised sill . SolicitouslyOh , I 'm sorry ! Did you hurt yourself ?STEWARD lays bags and satchels on seat , back to audience .Rather inconvenient , those doors , till you get used to them , but necessary to keep out the water in rough weather .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: L ., paying very little attention to STEWARD , only anxious to get rid of him and NITA so she may turn trunk over .You do n't anticipate a bad passage , Steward ?

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: R ., fussing aboutRather uncertain at this season , but your location is good , Madam , and you 'll find she 's as steady as a church .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Looking around as STEWARD arranges things fussilyThis is very pleasant .NITA arranges bags and grips on window seat .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Quite the best suite on board , Madam . Here is the clothes press , and the other rooms are off there .Opening door L. and closing it again .If you want anything —Points L .— there is the telephone .Notices trunk in middle of room for first time . Takes hold .I 'll place your trunk ——Starts to move trunk and drags it to side .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Quickly stopping himNever mind now , Steward . You can place it later .STEWARD releases trunk , but does not set it down .You might turn it right side up .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Noticing labelsOh , I 'm sorry !Turns trunk . PRINCESS sighs .I hope the contents are not upset , madam .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I hope not .

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Anything more , Madam ?

lg.stage: Anxious to get him out of room
lg.l: Not now , thank you ,
Steward . How soon do we sail ?

sp.speaker: STEWARD
sp.p: Very soon now .Voices off calling , “ All ashore ! ” four times ; voice approaches and dies away .They 're already calling “ All ashore , ” Madam .Exit and closes door .

div.stage: Nita . ( L. C . ) Your Highness has the key to this trunk ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: C .Yes — yes — you may — leave this trunk as it is , Nita , till later .Crosses to R .Go to your room and get settled ; then unpack the other trunks . I 'll call you when I want you .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Going toward door R .Yes , your Highness .When R ., near door , stops suddenly and timidly saysWill your Highness pardon me if I am mistaken in thinking I recognize the DUKE , your exalted cousin , among the passengers ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Without showing NITA that she is startled , but audience sees itMy cousin , impossible . He is at Madrid .

lg.stage: In excellent servant style , yet knowing she is right
lg.l: Yes , your
Highness .
lg.stage: NITA bows and exits R ., closing door .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Quickly fumbles with keys — selects right one , inserts in lock , unlocks and opens lid . Just as lid upAre you all right , Mr. Jarvis ?Knock at door as PRINCESS starts to raise lid .Wait ——Shuts down lid again . Knock repeated . PRINCESS crosses and opens door L ., disclosing DUKE . Exclaims in dismayCarlos ——

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Raising hat — standing in open doorFair cousin — if I but knew you were as pleased as surprised at seeing me .During speech he has entered ; takes PRINCESS ’ hand and carries it to lips and kisses it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why did you leave Spain ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Shuts doorFirst say you are glad to see me .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why are you here ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: R. C .Are you not glad to see me ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: L. C .Why , of course , Carlos , I — I 'm always glad to see you . But why have you come to America ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Who could bring me to America but you ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: How did you find me ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: It was n't easy . Spain had no attraction for me after you left , and I followed . Is not that true devotion ?Two long whistles . PRINCESS gets up confusedly as though she would not listen and goes to window back .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Up to window C .Oh , come ! We are starting ! Let 's go out on deck — I want one last look at America .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Thank you , cousin , I can do very well without it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Oh , Carlos , do n't be absurd ! Please .Whistle .We 'll be gone in ten minutes .She goes toward door . CARLOS gets up and opens it for her . Not wanting to , PRINCESS exits , followed by CARLOS , who closes door after him . Trunk lid raised slowly after PRINCESS and DUKE exit . JARVIS ’ head appears and looks about . Throws back lid and stands up . Gets cigarette and matches out of pocket , lights and smokes . Expresses satisfaction . Lifts one leg to step out of trunk ; gets stitch in back at movement .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oh — oh — Lord !Carries this business at far as legitimate . With every movement getting out of trunk finds new pain .If I only had that last baggage man by the neck ! Oh — a — oh , Lord !Crosses left and drinks water .Well , I 'm all here , most all .Feels elbow that is evidently skinned . Shoes are bent up from being doubled up in trunk . Sees them .My feet are bent .Goes to stoop down to get them — gets stitch in back . Drinks .Oh — oh — o !Hobbles over to looking glass , then to telephone R .Hello — hello — give me Mr. Jarvis ’ stateroom . Please — Jarvis — Warren Jarvis . No . I do n't know the number . All right .Pause .Hello — Rusty ? Come on up here quick and bring me an overcoat , cap and scarf . What 's that ? Hold on , I 'll see .Pause , then opens door L. and looks at number on outside ; shuts door ; back to telephoneStateroom A — promenade deck — and bring up that big bundle — quick , now !Hangs up — crosses and looks out window .Well , good-bye , America . I do n't know when I 'll see your shores again .Shuts trunk and sits on it .If Rusty gets here before that Exalted Cousin returns , I 'll be all right . Hm — ouch !— I wonder what the game is ?Knock at door .Go away — we 're all very ill .JARVIS , uncertain who it is , starts to hide . Door opens very cautiously . Enter RUSTY carrying bundle of trays taken in first act .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Looking over shoulderI knows where I 'm goin ’ , all right .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Come on in , Rusty .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Crosses to back of trunkHow did you get on board ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I came in that trunk .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: You came in that trunk ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Did you see any signs of the police ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Are you sure ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Did you look ?

lg.l: No , sir .
lg.stage: Handle of door R. rattles . JARVIS to open door . Princess enters .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: How de do , Mrs. Princess ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: How do you do , Rusty ?Exclamation C. R .Oh , there you are ! You 're all right , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Rubbing sore placesYes , I 'm all right .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But your hand — you must have that attended to at once .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That 's all right . I 'll see the ship 's surgeon .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Do , please .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: R .You can go now , Rusty . Oh , listen ! What is the number of your stateroom ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Number Seven twenty-nine .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Seven twenty-nine . Now get this : Go there , lock yourself in , and do n't talk to anyone . You 're deaf and dumb — understand ?— deaf and dumb .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I got you first .Exit upper deck .

lg.l: There is something I must tell you . My cousin , the Duke
D'Alva , is on board this boat .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: WhimsicallyHe professes to love you devotedly .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You overheard ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Pointing to trunkThe trunk . It was n't my idea , you know .With feeling — yet knowledgeYou are afraid of him ? Why ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well , he is very powerful — and I may be driven into his hands .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You mean — you might have to marry him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Looking nervously toward door C .Yes , if you fail .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Breath being taken awayIf I fail — Say , hold on a minute ! Things are coming too fast for me . I — you — how do I ——

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: InterruptingHe may come back any minute — and I do n't dare tell him what happened at the Manhattan Hotel — but he will want to know who you are and why you are with me .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That 's what I want to know . You forget I am completely in the dark .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Looking out of windowThe police can n't be on board now .Down stage .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Going to window beside her , and then back againYou can n't tell until you see who goes ashore with the pilot . They may be working on Rusty as a clue , but it wo n't lead them to anything so long as they do n't connect him with me . We 'll take no chances until we get past the danger line . Now let 's get down to business . What is the matter — and what am I to do ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: HesitatingI hardly know how to begin — it seems absurd in this broad daylight to talk of ghosts — but the fact is , my castle is haunted .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: LaughingSpooks ?

div.stage: Illustration : “ THE GHOST BREAKER ” See Page 34

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Very seriouslyCall it anything you like , but the castle is haunted , just the same . My grandfather was one of the wealthiest nobles in Spain . When he died my father went to take possession of his estate in Segura . He found the town full of weird stories of uncanny happenings — the castle was deserted , everyone had fled and all told of something in armor that stalked the halls at night .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: O-o-o-o-o-o-o-h !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: My father laughed at the silly natives and said he would go into the castle and show them how foolish their fears were . He went , and was never seen again .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Naturally deeply interestedWhat happened to him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: No one knows . He disappeared — vanished utterly , without leaving a single clue — and the treasure 's gone .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: More interested at word TreasureTreasure — what treasure ?

lg.l: My grandfather is known to have converted all his wealth into
Spanish gold . It amounted to about a million dollars in your money .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: How long ago was that ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Fifteen years ago . Since then two other men have disappeared — just as my father did — and now , the Duke tells me that my brother has entered the castle . You see it runs in the blood . Up to a week ago my brother had sent me a cable every day , then suddenly the messages ceased . All this week not a word . Now I know — my brother has entered the castle , and — well , that is the end .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Why did you leave Spain ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: A part of the legend was that a plan had been made showing just where the treasure was located — but this plan could never be found . Only by accident I learned that this plan had been hidden in the back of a locket and the locket , I discovered , had been sold and was in America . It was to find this locket that I left my brother and came here .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Then my work now is to find your brother and solve the mystery ? All right ! We 'll explain to the Duke that you are taking me to Spain for no other purpose than to solve the mystery . In America we 've had trust-breakers and strike-breakers , and now why not Jarvis , the Ghost Breaker ?

lg.l: Why , yes , why not ? Carlos would believe almost anything of you
Americans .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: WhimsicallyAnd you will tell him you have made me a — er — what is it ? A vassal ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Almost shylyI think not — not just yet .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: By the way , your — er — just how should a perfectly good vassal address his Princess ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: HesitatinglyHighness — is correct .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Highness — tell me , your Highness , a vassal does n't amount to much , does he ? I thought he was a piker .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: MystifiedA piker — a man who carries a pike ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Trying to explainNo , no — a piker is a tin horn .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Tin horn ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , a sort of pawn in this game of chess — along with your kings and queens and castles and things .Seriously , yet playfullyCould a good , hard-working , reliable vassal work his way up to be a Duke or a Lord , or something like that ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Almost playing with himYou 're an ambitious vassal , are n't you ? I 'm afraid you would n't be content with being anything less than a king .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: MeaninglyA king — a prince — or a bandit .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: A bandit ? And why a bandit ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: A king might command — a prince request — a bandit seize .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Seize what ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: DaringlyThat which a mere vassal can only admire .Knock at door . Both brought back to earth .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: There he is now .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Hooray !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What shall I call you ?

lg.l: Oh , any old thing — Warren , Mr. Warren .
lg.stage: Pause . PRINCESS crosses to door , hesitates a moment , then opens it .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Come in .

div.stage: Enter DUKE . Stops at sight of JARVIS .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Oh , I 'm intruding .Spoken as though he expected JARVIS to go .

lg.l: Allow me to present Mr. Warren , whom I am bringing from
America to solve the mystery of the castle . My cousin , Duke D'Alva .
Glad to know You .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: PatronizinglyI am honored . Interesting task you have undertaken . May I ask if that is your regular profession ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That is my business , solving mysteries , looking up the family skeleton , hunting out spooks . What we call in America a Ghost Breaker !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Ghost Breaker ? A strange calling . I indeed never heard of anything more extraordinary .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: It is not surprising , your Excellency . We are living in an age of specialists — and like every other profession , this calls for its own peculiar training .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: InterruptingI am so glad you are here , cousin — you will be able to tell Mr. Warren , so much better than I , all the circumstances .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I 'll be delighted to throw any light I can on the mystery , but first tell me —To PRINCESS— why did you leave your brother to come to America ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Takes locket from reticuleThis little locket is what brought me to America .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Crosses to her , holding out hand to take itMay I see it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Takes out memo .No , Carlos , you may see the locket — no one must see the memorandum .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Memorandum ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Seated on trunk — to DUKEA wise precaution .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Picking up locketCurious old piece of work — and you came all the way to America for this ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You were very fortunate to find it so soon .Cross R .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I knew where to go to find it — and yet I was nearly too late . Think of it , after that dear old locket had lain in an antique shop for ten years , suddenly in one day there came two inquiries for it .JARVIS sits looking at CARLOS .Mine was the second . A distinguished-looking gentleman had been there in the morning , described it roughly to the old man and got him to hunt for it . He had just found it when I came in . I doubled the distinguished-looking gentleman 's offer and got it .Another look at DUKE .Who do you suppose wanted that locket , Carlos ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: R ., being cornered and with effort to throw it off lightlyI see that it has already occurred to you that I am the distinguished-looking gentleman whose offer you doubled .

lg.l: But how did you learn about the memorandum ,
Carlos ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I did n't , Cousin . I had not the slightest suspicion that the locket contained the supposed secret . I was merely following my pet hobby , trying to recover some of those precious heirlooms which have been scattered to the four winds .QuicklyYou would be surprised , Mr. Warren , to see the collection I have already rescued and which some day may be yours , Maria .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Breaking in impatientlyWell , so much for the treasure . Now let 's hear about the ghost . What 's your opinion of this , your Excellency ? Do you put any stock in ghosts ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Warren , I am convinced there are such things .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You believe that this castle is haunted ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I know it .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You think this ghost is dangerous to encounter — that it is the cause of the deaths and disappearances in the castle ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I do .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , what do you think about that ? Ghosts —— That 's a pretty broad term , your Excellency . Can you tell me just what you believe this ghost is ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: There are certain occult forces in this world , Mr. Warren , that science cannot fathom , and some of them are manifested in that castle now . A priest might call it a demon or a fiend ; a psychologist , perhaps a returning spirit . I can n't say — but I know there is something real , a malignant force which lurks in that castle , and while it haunts those halls , it is madness for any man to expose himself there .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Have you ever seen this ghost ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: My brother has .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Twice .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Good night !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: So has my father , and the others when they disappeared . No one has seen it three times and lived .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Interrupting and looking at DUKEIn just what way do you connect this spook with the treasure ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Spook ? I see no connection . What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oh , there is always money where the ghost walks .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I do n't know what your experience has been , Mr. Warren . You are evidently a brave man — but you have yet to encounter a real ghost .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Brave ! It takes no bravery to fight a coward . That is what this ghost is — it 's a coward like every other ghost . I tell you that men are not half so afraid of spirits as spirits are afraid of men . Face the supernatural — and it is beaten to a frazzle before the fight begins . Spooks — horse-thieves — and peevish wild-cats can all be tamed by the same little charm .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: MystifiedCharm ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Leaning forwardWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I 'd hate to tell you . It 's part of my system .Taking out pistol .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: ScornfullyI had been hoping , Mr. Warren , that you had some subtle method of handling this problem , but you evidently propose to meet the forces of the supernatural with firearms . I — I may tell you that this specter has been shot at before without the slightest effect .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: SmilingQuite likely , your Excellency . I have seen rifle fire that had not the slightest effect on a wild-cat for the very reason that the firing was wilder than the cat .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: As though pitying himI am sorry for you Mr. Warren . You will find the ghost more real than the treasure .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: RisingBut the treasure is real , Carlos . Would I have crossed the ocean for this locket unless I knew ? Why , with this paper anybody — a total stranger — could walk right up to the very stone that hides it ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: MeaninglyPretty dangerous paper to have around . Look out somebody does not get there ahead of you .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Meaningly to JARVISYes , it is a dangerous paper — if it leads anyone into the castle .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: LaughinglyWell , your Excellency , I 'd go a long way for the fun of unravelling a good mystery with a little spice of danger thrown in .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You need n't have gone so far , Mr. Warren . You are leaving a very unusual case behind you in New York . The papers are full of it . Have you read them ?Picking up newspaper .It will interest you too , Cousin . You were at the Manhattan last night , I believe .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes !JARVIS and PRINCESS look at each other and DUKE reads from newspaper .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Why , no ——Glancing at trunk .I was so wrapped up in my baggage I really did n't have a chance .Looks at PRINCESS .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: “ Pistol duel in Manhattan Hotel . Colonel James Marcum , a prominent and wealthy Kentuckian , nearly met his death at five o'clock this morning in a pistol duel in his room at the Manhattan Hotel . ”Glancing down a little further“ At a late hour the police had no clue to the identity of his assailant , except the remarkable fact that the person is still hiding somewhere in the hotel . ”

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: InterruptingHe 's probably a long way from the hotel by this time .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Looking at paperThey say that he could n't have gotten out without being seen .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That 's the theory of the police or reporters .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What do you think ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: He might have escaped in a thousand ways — but that work is hardly in my line . That belongs to the “ Gum-shoes . ”

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Gum-shoes ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , ordinary detectives .Enter NITA .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: Excuse , Madame ——

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: No , Nita ! Not just yet . I 'll call you when I want you .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: We are keeping you from getting settled , I am afraid .Cross toward door .So , if you will excuse me , I 'll see you at luncheon , perhaps . Hooray ! I am glad to have made your acquaintance , your Excellency .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Thank you , Mr. Warren , I find you most interesting . I shall be glad to hear more of your remarkable profession .WARREN crosses to door and opens it , disclosing two detectives and steward .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Are you Miss M. T. Ar — ra — gan ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: L. C .Yes !

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: You was at the Manhattan Hotel last night ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: The lock on your door was broken ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Removes hatI am from headquarters , Madame , and I have orders to clear up one or two little matters with that affair at the hotel last night .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Orders , orders ! To break in here — what headquarters ?

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Police headquarters .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Do you know whom you are addressing ?

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Say — that will be about all from you !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , Carlos . Please let me attend to this matter . Wo n't you come in , gentlemen ?

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Thanks .Realizing they are already in the roomThat 's all , Steward .Exit STEWARD ; enter DETECTIVES , closing door . JARVIS slips wounded hand into coat pocket .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , we were just discussing that mystery , Inspector .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You are , I take it , one of the — er — gum-shoes ?JARVIS laughs and goes up stage .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Glaring angrily for a moment , walks over toward him and shouts in his faceGum-shoe ! Say , are you trying to be funny ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Well , sir , you are talking rather loud and with undue asperity . I presume I have offended you .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: You presume ! That 's a hot one ! Say , who are you , anyhow ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I am Carlos Hernando Duke D'Alva . I have other titles , but they would hardly interest you .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Dook de Alver — and then some , eh ? Ai n't that nice ? Well , if you was the Archbishop of Canterbury I 'd run yer in and take yer ‘ shore if yer give me any more lip !To PRINCESS , sucks his teeth contemptuously and turns his back on DUKE . Produces notebook from pocket and addresses PRINCESS .As you was saying when we was interrupted , you was in the hotel when the shooting occurred . Did you hear it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , I heard two shots .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Did you hear anything else ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , I heard some people running near my door .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Any one come in ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , my maid was frightened and came in .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Aha ! How did the lock on your door get broken ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: It was broken when I came . I explained all that at the hotel .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Um — all right . What about the colored man who came to your room and carried away a large bundle .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: That was my servant . I sent for him . They were purchases I made too late to put in my trunk . They are here , unopened ; you may examine them if you wish .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: That 's all right , Miss , but what do you know about this ?Produces knife from pocket — walks slowly to her , examining it .The initial on it is “ W . ”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Did I leave that ? Thank you . I 'm so glad you found it .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Then it 's yours ? Who is W ? Your name is Aragon , I believe .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I am Maria Theresa of Aragon .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: But who is W ?

lg.l: Why , er , it is n't W — you had it upside down . It is M — Maria
Theresa .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: That 's all right , ma'am . Now there 's just one thing more .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Cross and touch DETECTIVE on armYou will pardon me , but I wish to inform you that this man 's name is Warren ——

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Crossing toward himSay ! Who 's conducting this inquiry , you er me ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: But , my dear man ——

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: I am not your dear man . Cut that ! You get out of here .Forces him toward door .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , do go , Carlos . Leave us to attend to this matter . I am sure we can finish this better without you .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I merely wished to point out ——

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Interrupting and hustling DUKE outYou hear what the lady says .SECOND DETECTIVE cross to DUKE .Cut it , or out yer goes , and if ye butt in again I 'll fan yer . Do you hear ?SECOND DETECTIVE slaps DUKE on arm , motions him to door R .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: At doorInfernal outrage ! I shall report this to the King !

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: To the King , huh ? Did you get that , Tom ? Well , what do you know about that ?SECOND DETECTIVE closes door .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Do n't be disturbed , gentlemen ; he 's quite harmless . You heard him talking about the King — he suffers from Regalmania . He has grandiose ideas .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: AsideWhat does that mean , Tom ?

sp.speaker: SECOND DETECTIVE
sp.p: With gesture to headWheels .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: You mean he is crazy ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , he is at times ; but he is not at all dangerous .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: You lookin ’ out for him ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , that 's my job .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Sorry I had to be rough with him like that , Miss , but you saw he was gumming the game . I 'm going back to New York in the pilot boat shortly and there was n't no time to waste . Now just one question more . How do you account for the blood on that knob of your door ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Blood , on my door —— Why , I ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I think I can explain that , Inspector .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Go ahead , then .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Cross C .Allow me .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The colored man , the one you were talking about , the one who brought the bundle , that bundle there , carelessly broke the blade of that knife and cut his hand . That was it , was n't it ? You see the large blade is snapped off near the handle .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Where is this colored man now ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: He is in stateroom 729 .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: All right , I will just take a look at him . 729 ? Sorry to bother you . They was the Chief 's orders . Good-bye .Exit .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But his hand is n't cut .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Cross to ‘ phoneNo , not yet — but it soon will be . Hello , give me 729 .Pause .Hello , hello , hello , Rusty ? Damn it all , answer me , do you hear me ?Pause .Yes , I know I did , but I am telling you to talk now . Do just what I tell you and do it quick . Take your knife and cut your left hand . What ? No , no , you a — damned fool , do n't cut it off , but just enough to make it bleed a little and then tie it up with a handkerchief . Never mind . Do it quick , and remember , do n't answer questions . You 're deaf and dumb again .Hangs up receiver and turns to PRINCESS .By gee , you 're game ! You certainly buffaloed that Detective . Then your cousin Carlos broke in at the psychological moment to scatter their gum-shoe wits .Laugh .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: They believe he 's crazy .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: That 's just it . Now they wo n't listen to him . Yes , he 'll be crazy , all right . Do you think you can handle him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , you have your hand dressed .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Then I 'll hunt up the ship 's surgeon — and be back directly . Gee , you 're game !Cross to door R. DUKE enters at door R. JARVIS turns .Crazy ! That 's funny !JARVIS exits , laughing .

lg.stage: Showing suppressed emotion , stands R. C . glaring at PRINCESS
lg.l: Well !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Well , I 'm waiting !

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: For what , Carlos ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: For some explanation . Who is this man Warren ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: He is a professional ghost breaker , as he explained .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: How did you find him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I met him quite by accident .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What do you know about him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why , he is as well known in America as you are in Spain .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Indeed !Cross to center .Well , he will be better known when I turn him over to the police .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Why , Carlos , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I think you know that which I mean , Maria .DETECTIVE sticks head in door .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: It 's all right , Madame , but you might have told us that your nigger was a dummy .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: To PRINCESSOne moment , gentlemen , one moment .DETECTIVES enter .If this person is famous , these gentlemen should know him . Do you know Warren , the Ghost Breaker ?

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: The what ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: The Ghost Breaker !

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Both grinningHe 's off again , Tom .Enter JARVIS .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Now we 'll see . Is this man Warren , the Ghost Breaker ?Warren winks at DETECTIVES .

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: To SECOND DETECTIVEHe 's hip , all right .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Agree with anything he says .

lg.l: Answer my question — is this man Warren , the Ghost
Breaker ?

sp.speaker: DETECTIVE
sp.p: Now , that 's all right , Dook . Sure he 's a Ghost Breaker , ai n't he , Tom ?

sp.speaker: SECOND DETECTIVE
sp.p: Surest thing you know .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Sacristi , am I , Carlos Hernando D'Alva , to be mocked at by two grinning , bull-necked scullions ?Ship 's officer appears in door .

sp.speaker: SHIP 'S OFFICER
sp.p: Hurry up , there , if you 're going ashore with the pilot !

sp.speaker: DETECTIVES
sp.p: As they go through doorYou 're all right , Dook , old boy ! Ghost Breaker ! Ha , ha !They exit .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Crossing toward doorI 'll see the Captain .

lg.l: I think not just yet !
CURTAIN
ACT III

div.stage: SCENE : The main room of an Old Spanish tavern , Segura , Spain . Singing and mandolins heard from Wine Room . AT RISE , MAXIMO , an old discharged Spanish veteran , and GASPAR , a villager , discovered playing cards at table down C. This continues some time . MAXIMO slaps down cards exultantly , leans back in chair and laughs . GASPAR stares peevishly at cards . DOLORES discovered gazing out of window , D. L . Enter VARDOS , old follower of PRINCE BASILLIO , C. L ., carrying basket , covered by lid or napkin . Seeing DOLORES . Spaniard on steps . Lights full up , amber and white . Blue lights behind in windows , R. and L .

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: Still watching for a signal , Senorita ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Turning to VARDOSYes , Vardos . Have you any news ?

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: Nothing . Here 's the basket of food untouched as usual . This is the fifteenth night .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Once tonight I thought I saw a light in the tower , Vardos .

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: If you did , Senorita , it was an unblessed flame .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: You have n't given up hope , have you , Vardos ?

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: I gave up hope when the Prince went into the castle . Tonight I waited till an hour past sundown , and twice I called . Once a wail came back to me . It sounded like a sigh of the damned . When I called the second time , something moved in the turret of the keep , like a man waving ; and my heart leaped for joy . Then , with a harsh cry , a black , ugly bird flew from the turret straight toward where the sun had set — on my left , mind you , the sinister side , the left , the left !Castanets heard off stage , left .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Oh , if her Highness were only here .

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: What can she do ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: She would go straight to the castle , and will Segura have it said that they let her go alone as they did the Prince ?

lg.l: God forbid it should come to that .
Good night ,
Senorita .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Good night —Crosses C .— Vardos . You will go again tomorrow night ?

sp.speaker: VARDOS
sp.p: Yes , Senorita , willingly , until I know it is useless .Off stage voice : “ Bravo , Senorita ! ”Good night !Off stage voice : “ Bravo , Senorita ! ” Laughing and clapping of hands . Exit C. VARDOS .

div.stage: Exit MAXIMO , GASPAR and SPANIARD , door R. DOLORES lifts napkin and looks into basket ; crosses and exits D. R . Enter door L. C . ROBLEDO ; stands , looks about insolently for a second .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Eh — hey , you , Pedro !Receiving no answer , he crosses to table L. C ., bangs crop on table and shouts again .Hey , you , Pedro ! What 's the matter here ? Where are you ?Enter PEDRO , door R. Seeing ROBLEDO , is immediately scared and anxious to please .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Oh , Senor Robledo !

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Wake up ! What 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: One thousand pardons , Senor . What can I do for you ?

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: My horse is outside ; he has had a hard ride . Wash him off , and do n't give him any water until he is cool .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Yes , Senor , it shall be just as you say .Starting .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: And leave the saddle on . I may want to use him again .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Yes , Senor . Yes , Senor .Starts toward door C. ROBLEDO halts him .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Where is your daughter ?

lg.l: I will call her , Senor .
lg.stage: He crosses to door R ., calling .
lg.l: Dolores , Dolores ! She will come , Senor . She will come .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: And , Pedro ——

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Yes , Senor ——

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: If that rat-infested larder of yours is empty , get it filled before the Duke arrives .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: The Duke coming here , Senor ! When ?

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Tonight ! Do n't stand and stare . Hurry up and see to my horse .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Yes , Senor . Yes , Senor .Exit door L. C . DOLORES entering R .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Yes , Father ?Sees ROBLEDO .Oh , it 's you .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Pause — cross toward herWell , well ! Ca n't you say you 're glad to see me ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: I can , but I wo n't . Where 's my father ?

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Never mind your father . I want to talk to you .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: You do ? Well , you wo n't in that tone .Start to cross left .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Intercepting her C .I wo n't hey ?— And why not ? You little spit-fire !

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: What do you want to say to me ?

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: You little devil !She starts away ; he grasps her wrist .Come here !Throws her quickly and easily around stage L ., still holding her wrist .Say , what 's come over you these days ? You are about as fond of me and as sweet tempered as a tigress . What have I done ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: It is what you have not done , Don Robledo . For fifteen days your Prince has been in need of you and you have not had the courage to go to him .Enter MAXIMO door R. and beckons GASPAR and VILLAGERS up .Let go my wrist !Struggling . MAXIMO , GASPAR and VILLAGERS watch end of scene .Let go my wrist !

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Wait a minute ! Wait a minute ! You can n't get away . Do not try .She strikes him , frees herself and crosses L. to window .You little cat , I 'll trim those claws !VILLAGERS laugh . MAXIMO nudges GASPAR .

sp.speaker: GASPAR
sp.p: Sh ! sh ! sh ! Look out !

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: To themWell , what are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: MAXIMO
sp.p: Why , why ——Stammering .

sp.speaker: GASPAR
sp.p: A jest in the wine room , Senor .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Huh ! Lucky for you ! Get out of my way !Pushes them aside and swaggers through door R .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Gaspar ! Maximo ! Come here quickly !

sp.speaker: MAXIMO
sp.p: Crossing to DOLORESWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: GASPAR
sp.p: What is the matter ?Crossing to DOLORES .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: A light ! A light in the castle !

sp.speaker: GASPAR
sp.p: I thought I saw it a while ago .

sp.speaker: MAXIMO
sp.p: I do n't see it .

lg.l: But I tell you I did see it .
Father — Father — come quickly .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Entering R .What is it ? What are you looking at ?Cross C .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: L. C ., pointing out windowA light — a light in the castle . I saw it !

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Going to windowNombre de Dios .MAXIMO and GASPAR back to L. C .

lg.l: Well , why do n't you do something ?
Are you going to stand there like scared sheep , and let a man , your
Prince , signal to you in vain ?
Who 's the little devil tearing to pieces now ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: You , Don Robledo , sword-fighter , toreador , fire-eater , hero of a hundred duels — you — Don Robledo — coward !He chucks DOLORES under the chin . She throws his hand off .I asked you to go into the castle and rescue your Prince . I ask you now to answer the signal that I just saw in the tower window . Perhaps your Prince has just crawled to that tower window where he can see our lights . Perhaps he has burned something , a scrap of paper , in the hope that some of you gentlemen would notice it and come to his assistance , but he does n't know what cowards you are or he would n't have wasted his matches . Don Robledo — coward !

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Coward , never ! A fair fight in the open and I 'll meet the best man that walks the earth .Turns to VILLAGERS .Any two or three !To table L .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: I do n't ask you to kill one or two or three of these poor whimpering sheep ! I ask you to dare something .DUKE enters C .I ask you and these gentlemen —Point to VILLAGERS— to go to the aid of your Prince — and there is n't a man among you who dares ! God , how I could love such a man !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Down C ., sarcastically to DOLORESA pretty speech , Senorita !

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Seeing DUKE , removes hat and bowsYour Excellency !

sp.speaker: GASPAR
sp.p: The Duke D'Alva !VILLAGERS remove hats and bow to DUKE .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: His Excellency !

sp.speaker: VILLAGERS
sp.p: The Duke , His Excellency , etc .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Charming sentiments you express for your fellow townsmen , whose healthy common-sense prevents them from rushing to a fool 's death . Still , all fools are not dead yet . One of them will be here tonight . And you , Senorita , will doubtless be pleased to look upon him , as he has come all the way from America for the privilege of entering the castle and playing your hero .

lg.l: And did her Highness have to go all the way to
America to find him ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Yes , he 's from America , where all the fools come from .Everybody laughs but DOLORES . To ROBLEDOA word with you alone , Senor .

div.stage: ROBLEDO looks at GASPAR and MAXIMO . PEDRO , scared , motions VILLAGERS off to R. PEDRO , MAXIMO and VILLAGERS exit door R .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Can I get your Excellency anything ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Do n't mind me . I 'll look out for myself . Her Highness will be here very soon and will doubtless remain here for the night . I drove ahead to prepare you .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Yes , your Excellency !Bowing — exit door R .

lg.stage: Half sits on table L ., watches DOLORES off . To ROBLEDO
lg.l: You 've got work before you — Robledo .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: CenterI 'm ready , Excellency .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Rising , across to ROBLEDOYes , but this American may be dangerous .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: In what way ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Unless he is stopped he will go into that castle tonight — and I look upon you to stop him . He is coming here to solve the mystery and to find the Prince . I shall endeavor to stop him , but if I fail , Robledo , it rests with you .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: I can assure your Excellency I will convince the American that his presence in the castle tonight is quite unnecessary . Have you any instructions ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Any way you please , Robledo — means are of no consequence in this world . What I want is results . Only do n't underestimate your man . He will shoot , and I think he will shoot quick .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Good !Enter PEDRO door R. with tray and bottles and two glasses . Cross and put them on table up C .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Taking coin from pocketHere , take this and have them drink to my health and that of her Highness !ROBLEDO bows and exits R .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Is there anything else your Excellency desires ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Yes , hot water , soap and towels .Looks at hands .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: This way , your Excellency .Exit DUKE and PEDRO upstairs and off L .

lg.l: To his Gracious Excellency , the Duke
D'Alva !

sp.speaker: VILLAGERS
sp.p: Off stageThe Duke ! The Duke ! The Duke !

div.stage: Enter DOLORES R ., crossing to window L .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Louder , you beggars , louder , or I 'll give you something to yell for !

lg.l: The Duke ! The Duke ! Long live the Duke ! The
Duke ! etc .

div.stage: Lights seen of automobile approaching .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Her Highness !CallsFather ! Father !

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: EnteringWhat is it , Dolores ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Quick ! Her Highness is here !

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Her Highness !He bustles downstairs .Her Highness !Calls off R .Her Highness !

div.stage: VILLAGERS enter door R. Enter PRINCESS , NITA and JOSE in motor clothes . PRINCESS comes C. JOSE door L. NITA left center up stage . DOLORES L. C . PEDRO right center , C. VILLAGERS in door R ., bowing low .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Your Highness does my humble inn great honor ——VILLAGERS bow .

lg.l: Thank you .
lg.stage: She nods to VILLAGERS , extends her hand to DOLORES , who carries it to her lips , curtseying .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Your gracious Highness , we are ill prepared for this great favor . Your exalted cousin gave but short warning of your coming .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: My child , any place to remove the dust of travel will do for the present . Jose , I shall want the car later .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: L. C .Your Highness is not thinking of going on to the castle tonight ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I must have news .

sp.speaker: NITA
sp.p: But you 're all worn out . You 're all unstrung .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: When Mr. Warren comes , tell him I will be down directly .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: I will tell the Senor American , your Highness .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Thank you .Exit PRINCESS and NITA , PEDRO showing them upstairs .

div.stage: Enter JARVIS D. C .; followed by RUSTY , both carrying suitcases . DOLORES bows . RUSTY comes to DOLORES . JARVIS L. C . RUSTY crosses JARVIS to L. DOLORES returns bow .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Gentlemen — a man !

lg.l: Rusty , we 're discovered ! Did you by any chance address me ,
Senorita ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: I called the attention of these valiant gentlemen of Segura to the only man who dares to enter the castle .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: How did you know ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: All Segura knows by this time .

div.stage: Enter ROBLEDO door R ., pushing through VILLAGERS ; DOLORES tries to stop him ; he pushes her aside , swaggering toward JARVIS .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: So you 're the brave American , Senor ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I 'm an American .Turning to RUSTY on L .Here 's another one .RUSTY salutes .We 're both Americans .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: And you both want to die ?RUSTY makes wry face and big eyes .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: L. C .Well , I 'm not really anxious about it , Senor .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: Better keep out of the castle , then .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oh , you mean that ghost ? Oh , I 'm not afraid of a little thing like that , Senor .

sp.speaker: ROBLEDO
sp.p: No ?Turns to DOLORES C .Well , Senorita , we gentlemen of Segura will drink to your American .To JARVISThe maddest fool that ever came to Spain !ROBLEDO crosses to DOLORES , chucks her under chin , laughing . DOLORES throws his hand off ; motions Villagers off , and exits after them . JARVIS and RUSTY watch them off .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: He 's a nice man .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Pile the bags up there , Rusty .Put bags on table L .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Looks like we were in for a warm reception .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir , ‘ tis a trifle warm .Crosses below table L ., back to audience .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Pardon , Senor . Her Highness wishes me to tell you that she will be down directly .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Thank you , Senorita , and who , may I ask , was the cheerful individual that flattered me with such a toast ?

lg.stage: At C ., looking after ROBLEDO — crosses to JARVIS
lg.l: Don
Robledo , Senor .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Don Robledo — sounds dangerous , but does n't mean much to me .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: It may mean much before you reach the castle . Let me tell you something . Quick , your hand , Senor ! No , the other one .Grasps his hand .I 'll pretend to read your palm . Every one of those breaks in your life-line means a moment when you stood face to face with death , and yet , see those little squares of protection around each break ! Senor American , there is one break which you have not yet reached , and the protecting square is not perfect like the others .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I reckon that square will take care of itself when the time comes .

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: But the time is now , Senor .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: So — and are the senorita 's eyes so sharp that she can tell the day and the hour ?

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Not my eyes , Senor American , but my ears .DUKE comes downstairs .In all my experience I have seen but one hand like yours — it speaks of danger , and that hand belongs to Don Robledo .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Still on stairsWell , Mr. Warren !

sp.speaker: DOLORES
sp.p: Pardon , Senor !Curtsies to JARVIS and steps back from him .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Good-bye , Senorita . Many thanks for your occult wisdom . I 'll take good care of that little square .DOLORES crosses , bows to DUKE , exits R ., closing door .

div.stage: Illustration : “ THE GHOST BREAKER ” See Page 46

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Coming downWell , Mr. Warren , looking into the future ?Lays coat on table C. JARVIS L. C .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , Duke . The immediate future promises to be very interesting . A dark man is to cross my path .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: R. C .Do you believe in such foolery ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I like to , on this occasion , for I hope it means someone I very much want to meet .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Mr. Warren , I feel a certain responsibility for Her Highness ’ actions , and the prospect of your death tonight is most uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You think I wo n't come back ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I think if you go to that castle tonight you take your life in your hands .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I 've got a pretty good grip .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Look here . You Americans are shrewd traders . You get dollar for dollar when you bargain . You are not giving away your life for nothing . Now , what was the price ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Oh , not very much . The deal was made on bargain day . My life happened to be a little below par .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Very well , I will release you from your end of the bargain .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Your Excellency , I am overwhelmed , but the price is paid and we 're on the job , are n't we , Rusty ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir , we most certainly is !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I suppose that means that you will keep faith with Her Highness ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes .

lg.l: I never saw a man quite so anxious to be killed ; but there it is :
Fools rush in where angels fear to tread .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I 'd rather be an energetic fool than an angel with cold feet .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I am sorry for you .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Crossing to DUKEYour Excellency , I decline your offer and your advice and your sympathy , and I 'll tell you why . I once saw a gambler lay down four aces . Just think of it : four fat aces . He looked the dealer straight in the eye and said : “ The play ai n't natural . ” Now , you tried to have me arrested on the steamer , you have tried to block me in every move I have made . Now , all of a sudden you express the utmost anxiety as to what 's going to happen to me in the castle . You even offer to buy me off . You advise me to stay out . Shall I take your advice ? No . “ The play ai n't natural . ”

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You have intruded into a matter which you neither understand nor appreciate . If , as you say , the play seems unnatural , throw the cards and stay out of the game .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: No , I 'll stay right in the game , but I am going to watch the dealer . Well , come along , Rusty .Cross to RUSTY .Let 's see if we can find the landlord .Picking up bags .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I 'd like to find a piece of chicken .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Chicken , Rusty ? What put that in your head ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I 's powerful hungry , Marse Warren .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What — again ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: No , sir — it 's the same old hunger .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , Rusty , you are not going to get anything to eat until we finish the job .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Good Lord , have I got to wait till you 're dead before I eat ?They start with bags to cross to stairway . Enter PRINCESS on stairs .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Well , all Segura will be buzzing with your ghost hunt tonight . The whole town will sit up to hear of the outcome .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: And where are you going to get the returns , Duke ?

lg.l: Unfortunately , I must leave at once . I have an urgent summons to
Madrid .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , that 's too bad . I 'm sorry you 're leaving us . Wo n't you even be around at the finish , your Excellency ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I am sorry , Mr. Warren , but I must go .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , I call that a shame .

lg.stage: Coming downstairs — to PEDRO entering R .
lg.l: Pedro , this is
Mr. Warren . Attend to his wants .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: BowingYes , your Highness !PRINCESS crosses L. C . PEDRO goes upstairs .This way .JARVIS and RUSTY following PEDRO upstairs .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Your Highness , I 'd like a couple of good horses and two good lanterns .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Pedro .

sp.speaker: PEDRO
sp.p: Yes , your Highness .PEDRO exits .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Lanterns ? Looking for an honest man , Mr. Warren ?C. Lays hat on table C .

lg.l: Not in this neck of the woods , your
Excellency .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Carlos , what news of my brother have you heard ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: L. C .Nothing , Maria .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: And yet you are leaving for Madrid .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: The message is from His Majesty .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But why must you go so soon ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You know my ride is a long one .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: But , Carlos , my brother may be dying , dead — and yet you have not the time and the courage to help me find him .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What need of me ? You have your Ghost Breaker .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: So , Carlos , that is your excuse ?

sp.speaker: DUKE
