sp.p: I make no excuse , Maria . I need none . That Yankee adventurer stands between you and me . Send him away , and I will do anything you ask . I 'll put off my journey now to the King . I 'll send one of my men into the castle to find your brother .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , you will send one of your men — but you are not brave enough to go there yourself . Yet you ask me to send away this man who of all is willing to sacrifice even his life for me .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: If he stays , I 'll go .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Very well , then you force me to choose . I do . I choose a man .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You love him ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Perhaps .R. Turns away .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Well , Maria , you are sending him to his death .Enter JARVIS on stairs .Success to you , Mr. Ghost Breaker , when you beard the spectre in his den .Takes hat and coat from table .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Coming downstairsThank you , your Excellency .With mock dignityI 'll do my best .Changes expression .To put salt on the spectre 's tail .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Good-bye !Exit L. C .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: C .Mr. Warren , we must start at once .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Courage — if your brother is there , I 'll find him . You must be patient and remain here where you are safe , and try to rest .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: I cannot rest until I know what has happened to him . I shall go mad if I am left alone .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: But it is not safe for you to go .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Nevertheless , Mr. Warren , I will go to my brother tonight .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Now , my dear child !Pause .I beg your pardon , but please — oh , please let me insist on one condition .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Name it .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Let me go ahead and look over the ground . I will signal when it is safe to follow .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: How can you signal ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: With a light —Cross to window L .— from one of those towers . You can see it from here . You wo n't have long to wait . It will shine within an hour .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: L. C .But if you — if it does not shine ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , then I 'll be too busy swapping lead for brimstone with Mr . Spook to stop and hang a lantern .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Oh , but you are brave ! You must have the locket with the memorandum .Start to stairs .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Yes , of course , where is it ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: It 's in my room . I wo n't be long .On stairs .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Suppose you give me that , and we 'll start at once .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Very well .Exit upstairs and off .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: CallingRusty ! Oh , Rusty !

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: OffYas , sir ! Yas , sir !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Bring down my hat and coat . We 're starting .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: L. C .I would n't change places with that spook for all the gold —Enter RUSTY— that she thinks is in that castle .RUSTY comes down with hat and coat .Oh , do n't hurry like that , Rusty — I hate to see you hurry .

lg.l: I smell something cooking — smells like a
Spanish pork chop .
lg.stage: Gives hat and coat to Jarvis .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Calling from upstairsMr. Warren — Mr. Warren ——Darts up steps ; is met half-way by PRINCESS .Mr. Warren ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: The locket !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The locket gone ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: And the memorandum ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Gone , too .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Quick , Rusty ! The horses !

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: We 've no time to lose .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir .Exits .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Both on stairsYour Highness , I 've struck the first trail of the spook that is haunting your castle .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You think ——

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I think your cousin has not gone to Madrid . Time is everything now .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You know the way ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: North road — second turn to the right .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Yes , that leads to the postern gate .

div.stage: Enter ROBLEDO — stands in arch under stairs , revolver drawn .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I understand .Starting .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: Wait ! This little cross ! Will you wear it for me tonight ?Slips chain over JARVIS ’ head . ROBLEDO looks up and steps back in alcove .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Only for tonight ?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: You may never see tomorrow .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: If I do n't see you tomorrow , forgive me for telling you tonight that I love you .Raises hand to stop her reply .Do n't rebuke me tonight . Wait until tomorrow , if tomorrow ever comes .Pause .And now your humble vassal goes forth in his lady 's cause — and while all Segura waits , ghosts and Ghost Breaker shall stalk those halls . Your Highness , within the hour I will hang your signal from the castle .Carries her hands to his lips .

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: God be with you !Exits upstairs .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Watching her offHighness .— Highness ——Starts to go . ROBLEDO cocks revolver . JARVIS stops , listens , looks around , starts to fold coat , whistles “ Dixie , ” moves downstairs until near lamp , throws coat at lamp — lights out . Pause . Two shots are fired in the dark . JARVIS crosses left C. ROBLEDO crosses down R. C ., falls on second shot . Pause . JARVIS whistles “ Dixie . ” Exits door L. C .CURTAIN ACT IV

div.stage: SCENE : The Hall of the Knights , in the haunted castle . On walls a few old weapons , thick dust everywhere . Moonlight streams through round window high in wall R ., striking picture . Curtain rises slowly while orchestra plays “ I Dreamed I Dwelt in Marble Halls . ” Wind moans through grated windows , rats squeal and cross moonlight on floor ; light flickers on tower wall .
Enter JARVIS from door L. with lantern unlit — turns and calls cautiously .

lg.l: Come on in , Rusty .
They 've been in this room . Do you smell that , Rusty ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: L. C .Marse Warren , I 'm so scared I can n't smell nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The room 's full of it — somebody 's been carrying a smoky lantern .Dull thud off left .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Good God Almighty , what 's that ?JARVIS crosses R. C . over table , lights lantern and then stands looking around room .I want to go home !Put lantern down C .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Looking aboutWe 've been in this room before .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Is this where that poundin ’ came from ?Cross C. to Jarvis .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I reckon that pounding and the smoky lanterns went together .RUSTY sees armor on stairs ; backs into JARVIS and sinks to knees ; head on floor .

div.stage: Illustration : “ THE GHOST BREAKER ” See Page 62

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: O —— oh !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Whirls with gun drawnWhat 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Pointing to armor on stairsLook — look — look at them big black things — see ‘ em standin ’ there ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Laughing ; putting away gunThese are the same black things that scared you before — do n't you remember ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I 'm so scared I can n't remember anything !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: They 're nothing but suits of armor . Get up on your pins and do n't you bump me again .RUSTY rises .The next one of those rear-end collisions and I 'm liable to let some moonlight into you . You 've been treading on my heels ever since we came in here , and when I stop you bump into me .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I 'm powerful scared I might lose you !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: A fine chance !Looking about .Well , Rusty , we 've been through this old castle pretty thoroughly now , from dungeon to tower , and not a sign of the Prince or the Duke or any one else , unless they pound or carry a smoky lantern . It 's a clue , Rusty , it 's a clue . We 'll stick right here till we find out where it leads . I 'll swear the Duke never went to Madrid , but came straight here from the inn .JARVIS crosses to fireplace R. RUSTY follows .Get away from me .Strikes a match and holds in chimney .There 's a fine chance for a fire . Good , it draws . The chimney 's clear . Now , then , bust up the table and start a fire .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: How can I break it ? Oh , it 's rotten !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: You wo n't feel half so scared with a good blaze behind you .RUSTY picks up pieces of table .I 'll scout around a bit .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Drops pieces of tableDo n't you do no scoutin ’ outside this room !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , come on , Rusty — get busy and build that fire .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Dropping to floor and begins fussing with footJust as soon as I get this here shoe off .

lg.l: What 's the matter with your shoes ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: ‘ Tai n't my shoe — it 's my foot . You know I was holdin ’ them horses and waitin ’ and waitin ’ for you to come out . Dem guns went off and all dem horses jumped right on me .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: There were only two horses , Rusty .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I was countin ’ their feet .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , tie up your shoe and get busy .Looking around .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Yas , sir .Rises , picks up pieces of table , crosses to fireplace .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: This room was probably used as a banquet hall .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Gathering up few pieces of table and taking them to fireplace , puts them on fire ; looks upYeah — when we goin ’ to eat ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Not till we have finished this job .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Putting pieces of table on fire — still at fireplace , back to audienceTuesday — Wednesday — Thursday —— Ah can n't wait no longer than Saturday .Strikes match and lights fire . Glow from fire .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Runs up steps at back , looking leftThat way leads through those two long rooms to the postern gate .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Looking upThat 's where that black thing followed me .Crosses to JARVIS L. C . slowly .

lg.l: Well , a black thing followed me , treading on my heels every step
I 've taken .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Oh , I could n't see where I was steppin ’ .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Looking aboutThat goes to the Armory .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: L. C . JARVIS on stepsAh seen eyes in there , and a cold , grimy , green , slimy smell in there . Ai n't that where that broad-faced bird flew at me and I fell down them slippery stairs ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: LaughingThat broad-faced bird was an owl , Rusty — just a common , ordinary owl . You know what an owl is .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: O — ooh — ooh !

lg.l: Where can that door lead to ? That 's it .
lg.stage: JARVIS goes to the door in R. C . Steps on trap and falls suddenly .
lg.l: Wow ! That was a close one .
Lord , Marse Warren , what is it ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Get back ! Give me that lantern .RUSTY hands lantern .Give me your hand . Can you hold me ?RUSTY holds out hand and JARVIS cautiously steps on trap door ; it sinks and other end rises .God ! I thought so . Water and a long drop ! No wonder people disappear in this castle . Good Lord , what if her brother went down there ? Rusty , whatever happens , keep clear of this . If you step on this you will never see Kentucky again for sure .Groan heard off left .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Did you hear that groan ?Wind changes to low moan .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Groan —— There it is again . It sounded just like a man .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Ough ! Ough !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Shut up !Crosses to L. C .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Marse Warren — look out !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Listen !Crosses and stands moment at door . Wind moans .I guess it 's the wind .He crosses to fireplace .This place is getting on my nerves .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: R. C .That was n't no wind , Marse Warren . Ah hope to die if that was n't a sure enough human groan .He looks at picture L .And Ah want to tell you som'pin ’ else . Have you ever been in church or somewhere and all of a sudden a feelin ’ come over you that there was eyes a-starin ’ at the back of your head ? You just knowed it — until you could n't stand it no longer , and just turned around and see who it was ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Why , yes , Rusty , I have had that happen . Why ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: That 's just the way I feel now , like there was eyes a-lookin ’ at me .Turns to picture .You see that picture ? Seems like that feller was lookin ’ at me — like he 'd step right out of the frame .He points to armor on steps .Or them two battleship boogies — just jump right down here .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: It 's been a good many years since those boys jumped , Rusty .Noise off stage of running .Hark ! Listen !He crosses to L. C ., pistol drawn ; stands listening .Somebody 's running — coming this way ——Dull thud at back .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I want to go home !

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: What do you know about that ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: I do n't want to know nothin ’ about it .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I thought so .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: The man with a smoky lantern has been up those stairs .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: You ai n't goin ’ up there , is you ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: I am not — because the Duke or some of his men are probably waiting for me at the top of the stairs with a big long gun , and I 'm no book hero .

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Suppose it 's the Prince ?

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Well , suppose it is the Prince . He might blow my head off , because he does n't know what I came here for — and if it 's someone else , they 'll blow my head off , because they do know .

lg.stage: Looks at ceiling and following supposed sounds with head R. C .
lg.l: Sounds like somebody was runnin ’ round .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: C .They 're trying to scare us , Rusty . They 're probably watching every move we make . That 's where that pounding comes from . Why do n't they shoot ? They 're trying to scare us , like they did the poor boobs down in the village .RUSTY crosses to fireplace .They want to get us out of here . They want to get us out of this room . Rusty , someone was working in the room . Now , where was he working ? Where was he ——

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Meanwhile has crossed to mantel and picked up hammer and chiselLook here , Marse Warren — look y'ere !A few steps from fireplace .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Crossing to RUSTYWhat is it , Rusty ?

sp.speaker: RUSTY
sp.p: Handing them to JARVISLook at them .

sp.speaker: JARVIS
sp.p: Where did you find them , Rusty ?

Comedy in 4 acts by Booth Tarkington . 5 males , 5 females . 2 interiors . Costumes , modern . Plays 2-1 / 2 hours .

One of the “ five million ” , Clarence served where he was sent — though it was no further than Texas . As an entomologist he found — on this side of the ocean — no field for his specialty , so they set him to driving mules .

Now , reduced to civil life and seeking a job , he finds a position in the home of one Wheeler , a wealthy man with a family . And because he 'd “ been in the army ” he becomes guide , philosopher and friend to the members of that distracted family group . Clarence 's position is an anomolous one . He mends the plumbing , tunes the piano , types — off stage — and plays the saxophone . And around him revolves such a group of characters as only Booth Tarkington could offer . It is a real American comedy , at which the audience ripples with appreciative and delighted laughter .
Those marvelous young people , Cora and Bobby , are portrait sketches warranted to appeal to everyone .

A young automobile salesman just out of his ‘ teens inherits a girl 's school and insists on running it himself , according to his own ideas , chief of which is that the dominant feature in the education of the young girl of today should be CHARM .
In the end the young man gives up the school and promises to wait until the youngest of his pupils reaches a marriagable age .

“ The Charm School ” has the freshness of youth , the inspiration of a novel idea , the charm of originality , and wholesome , amusing entertainment . We strongly recommend it for high school production .

div.stage: Mrs. Fair was a major abroad and won a medal for bravery . Her husband was displeased when Mrs. Fair came home to a fame which lifted her out of his life . The dissatisfaction grew as she became absorbed in public functions . Mr. Forbes traces the widening of the rift between husband and wife with great skill in the first two acts . These are light comedy . In the third the mood becomes serious and we find that Mrs. Fair 's absence from home has set the husband to philandering and the daughter to intimacy with a gay set . Indeed , only through the joint efforts of husband and wife to save the girl from danger , is harmony again established . A true comedy , written with keen insight . Royalty , $ 35. 00 . Is it possible to tell the absolute truth — even for twenty-four hours ? It is — at least Bob Bennett , hero or “ Nothing But the Truth ” , accomplished the feat . The bet he made with his business partners , and the trouble he got into is the subject of William Collier 's tremendous comedy hit . “ Nothing But the Truth ” can be whole-heartedly recommended as one of the most sprightly , amusing and popular comedies . Sherman Fessenden , unable to induce servants to remain at his Jersey home , hits upon the expedient of engaging detectives as domestics . His second wife , an actress , weary of the country , has succeeded in discouraging every other cook and butler against remaining long , believing that she will convince her husband that country life is dead . So she is deeply disappointed when she finds she cannot discourage the new servants . The sleuths , believing they are called to report on those living with the Fessendens , warn Fessenden that his wife has been receiving love-notes from an actor friend , and that his daughter is planning to elope with a supposed thief . One sleuth causes an uproar making a mess of the situations he has witnessed . Fessenden , however , has learned a lesson and is willing to leave the servant problem to his wife .
